title: 114_hr4943
content: The Act may be cited as the "Tribal Tax and Investment Reform Act of 2016". The Congress recognizes the unique relationship between the United States and Indian tribes, acknowledging tribes' authority to provide programs and services, develop economies, and maintain infrastructure on reservation lands. Federal laws and treaties affirm tribes as sovereign governments with the power to tax, issue bonds, and receive tax exemptions. Tax parity for tribal governments aligns with treaties recognizing their sovereignty and addresses historic capital access challenges. Indian tribes face historic disadvantages in accessing capital for infrastructure and governance, hindered by statutory restrictions. They are sometimes excluded from key provisions in the Internal Revenue Code, leading to unfair tax treatment. Congress exercises authority to regulate commerce with tribes, promoting self-governance and affirming the government-to-government relationship. Indian tribes are treated as states for bond issuance under SEC. 3. Indian tribal governments are subject to special rules for tax-exempt bonds under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Secretary of the Treasury establishes a national bond volume cap for Indian tribal governments based on population estimates and allocates it among tribes seeking an allocation. Indian tribal governments can receive allocations for tax-exempt bonds based on population estimates. Section 7871 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to remove certain requirements, with effective dates specified for the changes. SEC. 4. Treatment of pension and employee benefit plans maintained by tribal governments. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include expanding the definition of qualified public safety employee to include Indian tribes and updating the definition of governmental plan to encompass plans established by Indian tribal governments or entities. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include expanding the definition of qualified public safety employee to include Indian tribes and updating the definition of governmental plan to encompass plans established by Indian tribal governments or entities. This includes exempt governmental deferred compensation plans and grandfathering certain tribal government plans established before the enactment date. Amendments to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 expand the definition of governmental plan to include plans established by Indian tribal governments or entities under Federal, State, or tribal law. This encompasses plans for employees of Indian tribal governments, subdivisions, agencies, instrumentalities, or entities wholly owned or controlled by them. Amendments to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 broaden the definition of governmental plan to include plans established by Indian tribal governments or entities under Federal, State, or tribal law. This covers plans for employees of Indian tribal governments, subdivisions, agencies, instrumentalities, or entities wholly owned or controlled by them. The amendments to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 expand the definition of governmental plan to include plans established by Indian tribal governments or entities under Federal, State, or tribal law. This encompasses plans for employees of Indian tribal governments, subdivisions, agencies, instrumentalities, or entities wholly owned or controlled by them. The effective date for these amendments is for years beginning after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. Tribal foundations and charities treated like charities funded and controlled by governmental funders and sponsors. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include Indian tribal governments, agencies, and entities under certain sections. These changes apply to taxable years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 6. IMPROVING TRIBAL CHILD SUPPORT ENFORCEMENT AGENCIES' ACCESS TO FEDERAL PARENT LOCATOR SERVICE AND TAX REFUND OFFSETS. Improving tribal child support enforcement agencies' access to Federal Parent Locator Service and tax refund offsets by amending the Social Security Act to include Indian tribes and tribal organizations eligible for grants under specific sections. The amendment allows Indian tribes and tribal organizations to access Federal Parent Locator Service and tax refund offsets, similar to how it applies to States with approved plans. The Internal Revenue Code is also amended to include Indian tribes and tribal organizations under the definition of "State" for this purpose. SEC. 7 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include Indian tribal governments for determining special needs under the adoption credit. The amendments apply to taxable years starting after the enactment of the Act.
